Vain world, depart; nor with thy smiles intrude!</br>Be this place sacred to most solemn thought!</br>Hush'd be the sound of voice or footstep rude,</br>While ages past before the mind are brought,</br>And silent musing is to rapture wrought.</br>For ever, here, be Folly's face unknown,</br>And be this temple oft by Wisdom sought:</br>That soaring youth may list her voice alone,</br>Reading of life's true worth from page of mouldering stone.

Lo, the vast works of ancient art are placed</br>The admiration of a far-famed land!</br>Yet when they first sprang forth to view, and graced</br>That goodly fane which doth a ruin stand,</br>Plunder'd, and midst its desolation grand,</br>This spot was an unpeopled wilderness;</br>Save here and there a little savage band,</br>Chasing the boar with barbarous address,</br>Or couch'd round mud-built huts, slumbering away distress.

Daughter of Beauty, calling Britain — Home!</br>Come pass an hour within this hallow'd place;</br>And when thy thoughts o'er distant ages roam,</br>The steps of Nature or of Art to trace,</br>Let not a form adorn'd with youthful grace,</br>Round which the loveliest hues of health may play,</br>Nor yet the sweetness of an angel face,</br>Thy love-fill'd heart to vanity betray:</br>For think, Oh!  think how soon ye pass from earth away.

Remember, fair one, though thy charms may vie</br>With the enchantment o'er these relics flung,</br>Though virgin love may light thy beauteous eye,</br>And in thy praise full many a lay be sung;</br>Forms, fair as thine, have o'er these marbles hung,</br>Whose ringlets wander'd o'er as bright a brow;</br>With whose sweet praise the minstrel's lyre oft rung;</br>Before whose smiles ev'n Science learn'd to bow!</br>Yet these all droop'd and died — Alas!  where are they now?

Brethren!  do ye too pause in manly guise,</br>Nor trifle in the presence of the great:</br>The statues of the mighty and the wise,</br>Long ceased from earth, here meet in marble state;</br>Pointing to men whose genius could create</br>Works to amaze the world throughout all time!</br>On whose stupendous labours yet await</br>Ages of glory; till their native clime</br>Perchance may rise again to state still more sublime!

Here ponder deep in solitude profound,</br>And back to years long past, awhile retire;</br>We tread, as 'twere, upon enchanted ground,</br>Where rang the echoes of fair Sappho's lyre!</br>And here are they who did her song inspire!</br>The harps of ancient bards ring forth again</br>The hymns o'er which our spirits never tire;</br>But pause to attend the soft, aerial strain,</br>And drink the fancied bliss from out the cup of pain.

A nation's fame here urn'd in marble lies!</br>The silent glory of departed days</br>Lives like the sun in eve's unclouded skies,</br>When lovely light around the spirit plays,</br>While the rapt soul inhales the radiant rays.</br>Pause here, and mark how giant Art doth wage</br>Battle with Time, who on his offspring preys—</br>Their names are read upon the sculptured page,</br>Whose works illume the world in this far distant age.

"Her dead are turn'd towards the setting sun,"</br>And Athens weeps o'er many an envied bier;</br>The race of glory hath been lost and won,</br>And Athens' woes implore the patriot's tear.</br>No more her sons the shout of victory hear;</br>Fall'n are her heroes, and her foes are strong:</br>Freedom's firm notes their hearts no longer cheer,</br>Raised to redress a much-loved nation's wrong!—</br>Hush'd is the minstrel's voice, ceased his inspiring song!

Yet Athens triumphs in her heroes' dust,</br>And conquers by the 'magic of a name.'</br>The ashes of her sons, a sacred trust,</br>For her, the homage of a world must claim,</br>Which boasts no mightier monument of fame.</br>The spirits reign the monarchs of the past;</br>Their memories live, like an unwasting flame,</br>From which bright beams o'er many realms are cast,</br>To light the path to Fame, as long as Art shall last.

Hark!  far-off music falls upon the ear,</br>Like the light sounds that haunt an honour'd tomb—</br>Delusion sweet!  as lone we wander here,</br>Within the confines of this narrow room,</br>Fancy recalls the spring-time, and the bloom,</br>Of Grecian glory; and we stop to muse</br>Upon the darkness of her latter doom;</br>And wonder how our country can refuse</br>Her aid, to crush the foes that such fair realms abuse!

I view the labours of the far-famed dead,</br>The wondrous works of many a mighty mind—</br>Broken but not destroy'd!  Their beauty's fled—</br>The new-born sweetness, pure, but undefin'd,</br>That flush'd them o'er when first they were design'd,</br>Their early loveliness is gone!  but now,</br>Youth's vigour, manhood's strength, and age, combined,</br>Have rear'd a throne to which the world must bow,</br>And torn a wreath from Time to bind round Art's bright brow.

The fragments here of fine hewn forms I see,</br>Which were the wonders of the world of old;</br>And ever will the pride of nations be,</br>Until the heart-blood of their sons is cold!—</br>Come nearer, and drink in the charm — behold</br>Where, in his hoary strength, Ilissus lies,</br>O'er whom the floods of many an age have roll'd,</br>Since first his mighty form was seen to rise—</br>Ere the great artist's soul had sought its native skies!

Rise!  Rise!  Old guardian of the peaceful stream,</br>And to thy ancient place of rest depart!</br>Lift thy huge bulk, that, fill'd with life, doth seem</br>From its hard seat e'en now about to start!</br>Strength nerve that arm if thou material art;</br>That foot firm grasp the ground without delay!</br>Though call'd a God, thou canst not upward dart,</br>And quit this spot, where thou art doom'd to stay</br>Till superhuman strength bear those large limbs away.

Time!  Time hath marr'd thee; and the solemn glance</br>Of thine unearthly eye is seen no more!</br>And ever dost thou seem about to advance,</br>An awful fragment, from the marble floor,</br>Where yet thou liest, still, as heretofore!</br>Say, where the remnants of thy form now lie?</br>Sunk in what sea, or scatter'd on what shore?</br>Shame that a God should, mangled, meet the eye,</br>The marvel of the wise, or jest of passers by.

Thou wert the offspring of a giant mind,</br>That tower'd above the spirits of the earth;</br>Born of a nation lofty, and refined,</br>Whose sons yet dream'd of Gods of mortal birth,</br>Whose attributes might half excite men's mirth.</br>Thou art a wanderer from that classic clime,</br>And art indeed of most surpassing worth;</br>Would I had seen thee in thy youthful prime,</br>Ere thy fine form was scathed by the rude hand of Time!

Sweet flows thy unprotected river still,</br>And shepherd swains upon its banks reside;</br>And the smooth waters pass by many a hill,</br>Down which perchance hath rush'd the crimson tide</br>When war's red hand that stream's fair bosom dyed:</br>Calm flows thy river, though long lost to thee!</br>Yet will not I thy shatter'd power deride—</br>Thou art no God from mortal frailty free,</br>But made by man to share his immortality.

And doth thy temple on the brink still stand,</br>Of that clear current, where it erst was rear'd,</br>Whither, of old, went many a rural band</br>Of worshippers, thy shadowy power who fear'd?—</br>Or, with the beams that once the nation cheer'd</br>From Art's fair sun, now risen on Britain's isle,</br>Have both the fane and idol disappeared?</br>And is not one poor relic left awhile,</br>To cheer her children's hearts with memory of a smile?

Well, well — our years roll on like ocean's waves,</br>Which all things in their mighty way do sweep;</br>And tyrants help at length to fill the graves</br>Where thousands of their gory victims sleep;</br>For they who sorrow sow, affliction reap.</br>O'er Athens, now, despotic darkness reigns—</br>Her country groans — yet let not Athens weep!</br>A new-born hero yet shall tread her plains,</br>And rise, like him of old, to snap her hated chains.

Here Athens' king reclines, his labours o'er;</br>His fine limbs stretch'd in undisturb'd repose!</br>Theseus, thy work is done; and never more</br>Thy roused strength shall crush thy giant foes:</br>Ceased are thy toils, with all thy warlike woes!</br>Thy tasks Herculean all completed are:</br>But Grecian annals to the world disclose</br>A tale, which stains thy reputation fair—</br>Of Cretan monster slain, and Cretan maid's despair.

Lovely thy mutilated form appears!</br>Oh valiant monarch, how couldst thou endure</br>To look on Ariadne's starry tears?</br>What shall this world from cruel deeds secure,</br>If heart so hard could dwell in form so pure?</br>Wert thou indeed so beautiful of mien?</br>Or hath the sculptor's art, the world to allure,</br>Bestow'd on thee an aspect so serene?</br>Thou wouldst not seem so fair if thy lost love were seen!

Thy heart was hard, great king, to murder love,</br>Whose earliest seed was in affliction sown;</br>Scarce may thy name deserve to rank above,</br>For such dark deeds in Heaven are never known.</br>Thy death was cruel, but could not atone</br>For sad desertion of a weeping maid:</br>Thy memory then is best preserved in stone;</br>For thus thy nature is at once display'd,</br>And thus in Pluto's realms thou wert of old delay'd!

Happy art thou, in that thy name doth live,</br>'Shrined in the glory of the artist's fame,</br>Whose hand an immortality could give,</br>Vast as surrounds the Theban hero's name,</br>To rival whom it was thy fruitless aim—</br>How many, richly fraught with virtues rare,</br>Whose patriot deeds thy famed exploits might shame,</br>No honours like to thine shall ever share,</br>But die away from earth without a nation's care!

Latona, where art thou?  In Delos' isle</br>Thy everlasting home should be; where night</br>Looks lovely from thy meek-eyed daughter's smile,</br>And thy son's presence maketh day most bright!</br>Apollo and Diana link'd in light!</br>Fair twins, aye join'd in Love's aerial chains,</br>Walking the skies to gladden mortal sight!—</br>Not long their light one favour'd spot retains:</br>Their beams are scatter'd far o'er earth's remotest plains.

Thy tale, Latona, hath not ceased to claim</br>Some tender sympathy — perchance a tear!</br>Surely 'twas meant to shadow forth the same,</br>That such a fragment only should be here!</br>And that thou should'st so desolate appear,</br>Thy smiling children parted from thy side;</br>Whose lonely birth must them to thee endear,</br>Born on an island in the ocean wide:</br>These thoughts so fill our hearts, we half forget to chide.

Pale, pale, fair sea-nymph of the brilliant wings,</br>Iris!  where hath thy rainbow beauty fled?</br>Art thou the messenger from heaven, that brings</br>Tidings of sunny peace in tempests bred?</br>Oh, with what airy lightness dost thou tread,</br>Thy dainty garments streaming in the wind!</br>Like a young spirit soaring from the dead,</br>Just on the point of leaving earth behind,</br>The ethereal realms to reach, and traverse unconfined.

Minerva's battles, and old Neptune's deeds,</br>Here, in loose fragments, float on memory;</br>Like ancient wrecks bedeck'd with smiling weeds,</br>On the dark billows of a solemn sea:</br>Hyperion, too, emerging bright and free</br>From the deep gloom of hoary Ocean's caves:</br>And Night, descending to the main, where she</br>Her star-girt chariot, in the morning, laves,</br>Plunging her coal-black steeds deep in the midnight waves.

Look on that head all motionless as death!</br>Though life seems flashing from the fiery eye,</br>And the proud nostril seems to strive for breath,</br>As if the snorting steed, too strong to die,</br>Had just been struck by lightning from the sky</br>And changed to animated stone; how strive</br>The marble muscles Reason to belie!</br>And by the magic might of Art contrive</br>To force the mind to yield and dream them still alive!

And here is many a monumental urn,</br>Telling sad tales of unavailing woe,</br>Of souls departed never to return,</br>For whom affection's tears have ceased to flow;</br>The mourner, with the dead, long since laid low:</br>And the frail vase, too faithless to its trust,</br>Hath let, alas!  its sacred treasure go,</br>The relics of the dead!  whose ashes, thrust</br>From these their little homes, are mingling with the dust.

Pass on, and muse upon the warriors' doom,</br>The men who fighting for their country fell:</br>Here is the epitaph!  But where their tomb?—</br>Ask not:  for that hath learning fail'd to tell;</br>And we may now but wish their spirits well.</br>Then turn away and yon inscription read;</br>O'er which the tenderest heart will longest dwell:</br>It speaks of beauty fall'n; and seems to plead</br>For something more than tears, pale Sorrow's wonted meed.

Ah me!  I ween half sad must be this strain;</br>For relics rise at ev'ry step, to bring</br>The recollection that earth's glory's vain,</br>Which Time so soon o'ershadows with his wing.</br>Enough!  We will, not longer stay, to sing</br>Of the bewitching groups of ladies fair,</br>Dancing with Grecian youths, as they would spring</br>Up from the stone into the vaulted air,</br>And, like half-heavenly things, their sport continue there:

Nor of the forms so exquisitely sweet,</br>Seen in procession as they pass along:</br>Where people strange of every order meet,</br>And to the temple of their idol throng.</br>Where is the light-limb'd boy, and warrior strong,</br>The veiled priestess, and the virgin band</br>Destined to sing aloud the sacred song,</br>Holding the written hymn with tasteful hand—</br>Girls chosen from amongst the noble of the land!

And graceful women, tall, and delicate,</br>Bearing the gifts on altar to be laid:</br>With vase and candelabra, all in state!</br>And, true to nature, in the stone display'd,</br>Until that love-sick fancy wooes some maid</br>Among the fairy company.  And then</br>Chariots arrive, and horsemen rich array'd,</br>And youths for ever young, and aged men,</br>And officers of state, with many a citizen!—

Shall earth ne'er see a second Pericles,</br>The slumbering genius of a world to wake?</br>To rouse the energies of men like these,</br>Of whose rich thoughts our spirits now partake</br>And are refresh'd?  When, when will princes make</br>Again such use of riches and of power?</br>The pomp of fashion, and false show forsake—</br>Ceasing to build but for the passing hour—</br>And some great fabric rear which Time may not devour!</br>
